title: 108_hr4431
content: The Act may be cited as the "One Church, One Child Act of 2004". The Congress finds a shortage of qualified foster and adoptive parents, with a decrease in foster parents despite an increase in children in foster care. There is a dire shortage of adoptive parents, with many children awaiting adoption for long periods. The increase in adoptions from foster care has created a need for post-adoption services. One Church, One Child is a national foster care and adoption ministry founded in 1980 in Chicago. It aims to provide services for at-risk children and support adoptive families. Despite its success, the organization receives limited federal funding. A federally-funded grant program to support similar programs could benefit abused and neglected children. One Church, One Child aims to support at-risk children and adoptive families. Increasing the pool of qualified adoptive and foster parents could benefit abused and neglected children. SEC. 3. ONE CHURCH, ONE CHILD GRANTS. Amends Part E of title IV of the Social Security Act to include "ONE CHURCH, ONE CHILD GRANTS." This initiative aims to support at-risk children and adoptive families. The Secretary will provide competitive grants to eligible entities for One Church, One Child foster parent and adoption recruitment programs. Eligible entities include state or local governments, public agencies, nonprofit organizations, and faith-based groups. Grants will support the establishment or expansion of programs to recruit and train foster and adoptive parents, as well as provide support services to children and families. The Secretary will provide competitive grants to eligible entities for One Church, One Child foster parent and adoption recruitment programs. Applicants must submit an application with project descriptions, coordination efforts with state and local entities, and services for prospective adoptive and foster parents. The Secretary will provide competitive grants to eligible entities for One Church, One Child foster parent and adoption recruitment programs. Grants are limited to $20,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2005 to 2009, with a requirement for entities to maintain records, submit reports, and cooperate with oversight. The Secretary will redistribute any unspent grant funds to eligible entities in need. Religious organizations will be considered equally for grants, as long as they comply with the Establishment Clause. Religious organizations can participate in a federally funded program without altering their internal governance or removing religious symbols. However, funds cannot be used for sectarian activities, and these organizations must adhere to fiscal accountability regulations similar to other non-governmental organizations. Religious organizations receiving federal funds must adhere to accounting principles and keep the funds separate from other organization funds. SEC. 479C. National Clearinghouse for Adoption Promotion and Foster Parent Recruitment Programs; Annual Report to Congress. The Secretary will contract with a nonprofit organization to assist in coordinating activities for recruitment of foster and adoptive parents, providing post-placement support, and offering technical assistance and training to grantees. The Secretary will contract with a nonprofit organization to assist in coordinating activities for recruitment of foster and adoptive parents, providing post-placement support, and offering technical assistance and training to grantees. The organization will identify and disseminate best practices for recruiting and training prospective foster and adoptive parents, collect information on program effectiveness, and assist in preparing required reports. The nationally recognized nonprofit adoption promotion and foster parent recruitment organization selected by the Secretary must have experience in providing consultation and training to faith-based and community organizations, a national reputation in recruiting and training foster and adoptive parents, and experience in programs based on the One Church, One Child model. The Secretary is authorized to appropriate up to $1,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2005 through 2009. Annual reports must be submitted to Congress detailing the number of entities receiving grants, foster parents and adoptive families recruited, children placed with them, and outcomes of placements. Additional relevant information may also be included for program evaluation under section 479B.
